The film is not absolutely dreadful. It's just not original or fascinating which is not a punishable offense in most states.
Despite its familiarity, something is amiss in Guy Ritchie's soapy, bland rehash.

There are efforts made, whether through good faith or just market savvy, to update Princess Jasmine into a people's champion who might prefer ruling to romance. Enough to make you wish the Disney people had gone whole hog and just called it Jasmine.
Ritchie failed to bring his signature style to this forgettable Disney reboot.
The nonhuman element (Abu) is great; there is also a perfectly charming Magic Carpet. There is just an unfortunate shortage of magic.

With "Aladdin," they've done the leveling with just enough style and pizazz that most moviegoers won't care that it's a retread, and the leads are good enough to make you hope they'll go on to something real.

Title: Dances with Wolves
RottenTomatoes: This epic was made by a bland megalomaniac (The Indians should have named him "Plays with Camera"). You look at that untroubled face and know he can make everything lightweight.
Even with its flaws, Dances With Wolves is cause for celebration, a haunting elegy to the end of the Great Plains wilderness.
It's difficult for any actor to direct himself effectively. It's amazing when someone does it in an epic that turns out as fine as this tale of the Old West.
Dances With Wolves is an audacious personal film, done big and done right. Somewhere John Ford must be nodding his approval.

Beginning with [a] kind of comically earnest freshness, Dances with Wolves stretches into an engaging, noble, epic vision worthy of filling a screen so wide it seems to literally sweep from sea to shining sea.

It is a personal story played out in a wide-open setting. It has stunning action (especially a breathtaking buffalo hunt) and moments of serenity. But the one thing that sets this frontier story apart from the norm is its dignity.
The result is big, muscular and full of theme. It’s also clumsy and obvious, but there hasn’t been a first film of this sheer bravado since Robert Redford made Ordinary People.
It's corny in spots, and it could benefit from a good, hard edit. But it still works well, benefiting from handsome photography, strong performances and a surprising amount of humor.

In its finest moments, and there are plenty, the film combines the straightforward, elegiac storytelling of John Ford with the mythic violence and imagery of Sam Peckinpah and the dark, absurdist humor of Monte Hellman.
It’s much more than good intentions: It’s good movie making. Dances With Wolves is an exhilarating adventure in a spectacular Western landscape.

Even if the camera technique is occasionally laughable, this is also an enjoyable, stirring, and extremely conscientious old-fashioned movie, with some essential things done right. It's the best movie Robert Redford never made.
A conservationist Western? An eco-Westem? Dances with Wolves wears its New Age labels with casual pride and, more importantly, rises above them.

It is part of the business of filmmaking to put arguments simply and even simplistically at times/ But when it is done as well as this, by (of all people) a Hollywood star in his first feature, we should all raise a cheer.

The film is saved by a laudable attempt at ethnographical accuracy, by the uncluttered simplicity of its storytelling and -- most of all -- by a humanity that only occasionally threatens to slide into sentimentalism.

Although everyone involved is under the impression that the film is an epic, it is actually a pastoral with flurries of action, an idyll with ructions rather than a vision of heroic struggle. There is nowhere near enough conflict to justify [its length].

Kevin Costner, one of Hollywood's new generation of star actors, makes a splendid debut as a director with Dances With Wolves, an ecologically sound, gloriously romantic and buoyant, if over-inflated, tragicomic Western.

On paper, Dances with Wolves looks like another Heaven's Gate... But not  only has this epic successfully disinterred a long-buried genre, it's a triumph on all levels that establishes Costner as a born film-maker.

Once it gets moving, Kevin Costner's homage to the Indian horse culture of the northern Great Plains becomes an irresistible force, taking the viewer on a long and sometimes bumpy but ultimately very enjoyable ride.
By never falling into the trap of allowing spectacle to supersede character, Costner's Dances with Wolves restores depth, idealism, poignancy and even wonder to a genre that had long seemed moribund.
It's an engrossing tale, and Costner directs with the confidence of a Hollywood veteran well aware that entertainment comes before earnestness.

Title: Paris, Texas
RottenTomatoes: The panoramic vistas from the cinematographer Robby Müller are as breathtaking as any John Ford western, while the naturalistic performances and deft narrative structure make this the strongest movie in the career of its director, Wim Wenders.
... An eerie, sad story whose meaning disappears over the vast horizon as if on a highway heading away through the desert.

It's a striking, gripping film for most of its length, with Wenders and cinematographer Robby Muller showing a great love of and fascination for the land -- almost as if their European upbringings had made them slightly envious of the wide-open spaces.
It is clear-eyed and unsparing, and full of the price our way of life extracts from those who can least afford it emotionally.
The movie belongs to Stanton, of course, and it's hard to think of any other actor who can go from Chaplinlike outcast to tragic hero in the space of a feature film.
It would be worth seeing for Stanton's performance alone.
A rewarding story of distance, separation and ultimately, of renewed chances.
"Paris, Texas," despite its history of last-minute rewrites, is unsentimental adult entertainment.
I've seldom seen such a potent combination of superior talents. Watch the first hour of the movie, and what you will see is an unparalleled summation of America as seen by wondering European eyes.
What separates "Paris, Texas" from most of today's movies is its gentle humanism.
A deeply affecting film about family, separation, loss and a man's last act of repentance.
The glum truth seems to be that Shepard and Wenders have let a great film get away from them.
If this film doesn't successfully indict the destruction of the nuclear family, no film can.
Paris, Texas may be missing a crucial piece of authentic Americana, but it still evokes an America most Americans yearn to gaze on.
It is true, deep, and brilliant.
